Short version: 83%Serious Sam can be considered the epitome of old-school FPS games: 100% pure action, non-linear levels filled with secrets, and hundreds upon hundreds of monsters to kill with a vast arsenal. Mindless first-person combat has rarely been this fun.Long version:When CroTeam, this small Croatian studio released Serious Sam: The First Encounter in 2001, probably even they didn’t think that their game will grow into one of the most successful indie FPS franchises. After all, on the surface, it looks like any other shooter from around 2000: half-linear levels where it is impossible to get lost yet have enough room to hide many secrets, all full of pickups to supply the player with health and ammo for the sizeable arsenal.The trick is that this simplicity hides excellent game mechanics. The action rarely stops, but it doesn’t try to tire out the player by not giving enough breathing room. The difficulty levels offer a balanced challenge to FPS newbies and grizzled veterans alike. (Just to illustrate: on ‘Serious’ difficulty, you meet over six thousand enemies during the course of the game.)The range of difficulties is only overshadowed by the available option in the engine itself. The Serious Engines were always famous of letting the player take control, but the first one really takes the top. Thanks to this awesome flexibility, the game ran on anything back then and looks surprisingly good even today, despite its old age.I’d lie if I said CroTeam put too much effort in the story: you play as Sam Stone, who was sent back to the source of all evil, ancient Egypt, to stop an alien warlord from eradicating humanity in the far future. Still, the writing is quite memorable, thanks to the corny one-liners and the overall nonsensical nature of some of the encounters that help to alleviate the stress after some especially adrenaline-pumping scenario. So, in a sense, the “story” does its job, like the rest of the game.

I guarantee that you will not want to stop playing this game after you finish the first level. It's the type of game that elevates your dopamine levels and excites you to the max. BUY this game if you wish to be entertained and have a couple of laughs now.

												Serious Sam The First Encounter can easily be taken as a tribute to Duke Nukem with a similar style of both gameplay and storytelling. That is not to say that it isn't a game that can stand on it's own though as a solid dose of juvenile shooter action.The premise of Serious Sam is simple enough, you are the most badass dude on on earth and you have to kill a bunch of aliens in order to save humanity. The game knows that it's story is not important and makes no effort to hide the fact that the only purpose of the few tidbits of writing you get every once in a while are simply there to make sure you know it's a single player game. What Serious Sam is about however, is the shooting.Much like Duke the main character, Sam, is no power armored pansy. He doesn't need cover systems, regenerating health or turrets to kill his way to the alien overlords. The weapons are many and varied although the lack of anything equal to the shrinker makes me a little sad though. The combat is fast and furious your only protection against the multitude of projectiles being thrown at you is your skills at dodging, and of course, you ability to kill stuff so it stops shooting at you. The levels are huge seemingly unending at times and the game throws legions of enemies at you at a time making for some of the most hectic action I've experienced in recent years. Similar to Duke the levels are also littered with secrets and shortcuts that rewards the attentive players among us.Graphically the game looks good without impressing too much, a good enemy variety and a decent amount of detail in the level design ensures that the graphics only add to the experience. The music is somewhat bland but the sound effects are of a decent quality and Sam's one liners are well delivered.All in all Serious Sam The First Encounter gives you a great first person shooter experience the way it's meant to be played, fast, hard and hectic. At a good price point even on release this should be a must own for every serious FPS'er.

												Serious Sam First Encounter is a classical example of how to create a good game which one can spend hours on without ever growing tired of playing. While it is already old, it is by no means outdated. (With perhaps the exception of the graphics, but hey, that's what happens with any game if more than 10 years pass) Don't mind my lack of gametime on steam - I must have over 100 hours throughout my childhood on this game, it's amazing, and I can recognise it isn't just nostalgia making me say that.Storywise, it's nothing to write home over. It's a fairly standard story for a game that relies more on its gameplay than on captivating you with word words and more words. Aliens happened, they're after you, you're in acient Egypt and you have guns. Good luck!There is more to it, if you take the time to read into the story there are just enough flavourful blurbs and explanations around that you can read to figure out where your enemies came from, and parts of the storyline, though it isn't something that will carry you through the game, it's more like an extra.The true power of Serious Sam is in the gameplay, with excellent level design, guns that are satisfying to use, and a very high skill ceiling allowing you to feel like a god laying down devastation on hordes of enemies, moving fast enough to dodge almost all of their fire (Since all but a few enemies use projectiles, this means you can dodge nearly everything with enough practice) yet not too fast to become unmanagable. This, along with plentiful secrets, and a game that won't just say 'no' and throw up an invisible wall if you move slighly off the beaten path means that Serious Sam has an excellent grasp the concept of what great games are about- FreedomFreedom to choose your own tactics (And most are valid as well! No need to gimp yourself)Freedom to move as you pleaseFreedom to explore the levels and find all the secretsAnd the freedom to handle any encounter in the way you want to.Along with this, Egypt as pictured is a somewhat unique setting for an FPS game, with a lot of it lending itself for interesting levels and impressive scenery. The enemies you face are unique and mostly iconic as well, with the beheaded bomber and kleer skeleton being some of the more known enemies. In addition, Serious Sam has a great sense of humour, and you can play with a friend, two friends, or a whole army of friends.If you're interested in a great FPS game and don't mind slightly outdated graphics, Serious Sam is there for you.And if you do mind the graphics, check out the HD version! It's worth it

												Serious Sam The First Encounter is a decent "old school" FPS. You go around blasting various alien enemies with various guns. The game feel is good with Sam moving around. The weapons each have their own advantage against certain enemies. You won't be using the same gun the entire game. I was constantly switching weapons based on what was coming toward me. The weapons I would say are pretty "standard". Pistol, shotgun, machine gun, rocket launcher, laser gun, etc. Each having their own advantages and disadvantages. The amount of unique enemies is fairly small. You'll be seeing the same types of enemies over and over again. The design of them is nice though. Each enemy has a distinct audio clip that you will rely heavily on to quickly choose the right weapon for the job. I think the graphics hold up quite well. I was able to get the game running in 2560x1440 and it was very sharp. One thing that turned me off was the large difficulty spike toward the end of the game. It's a pet peeve of mine when games sharply increase the difficulty at the end. I had to use God mode to get past it. Pros:-Good graphics for the time that still hold up today-Good gameplay feel and hit detection-Audio cues for enemies-Each gun has advantages & disadvantages-Quick save feature-Stable. Never crashed on me (windows 8.1 64bit)-Secret areas!-Generally smooth 60FPS (has some slowdown here and there but didn't affect much)Cons:-Lackluster story-Repeating enemies-Difficulty spike at the end-Felt repetetive toward the end of the game6/10 Good. Slightly above averageI got Serous Sam Classic 1 and 2 by buying Serious Sam Classics: Revolution  for $1.49. Fantastic deal!!!Even $9.99 full price isn't bad considering you get 2 games with it. 												One of, if not my favorite game of all time. Serious Sam TFE displays what an arena shooter can pull off.The storyline? It sets the mood, that's about it, and that's all it really needs to do.You are sent into the past to kill off hundreds upon hundreds to even thousands of enemies from destroying the future. Simple enough?Serious Sam introduces literally the most memorable foes in any video game I've ever encountered. I remember each name, and all the stats because the game throws them in your face in a way that actually satisfies. Two shots per beheaded soldier, a quick shotgun blast to male Gnaars, double shotgun for those damn Kleers, loaded cannon to the major Biomechs! The best part is that these enemies rarely appear in troops, but in groups! You'll have a Biomech on one side, an Arachnoid on the other, an Aludran Reptilioid on the roof... how will you choose to approach this? It's all up to you and your powerful arsenal!Something also notable about Serious Sam is the stunning detail. Each enemy has a spot-on texture to make it feel like a true foe, and writings, paintings on the wall give for a total immersion into the mysterious landscape of Egypt. And how damn satisfying that is.Running through factual lands to kill fictional beasts has never, EVER been so pleasing. With a unique arsenal and engaging gameplay, Serious Sam gives you an un-parallelled journey to the beautiful land of Egypt with true to history level design.I could go on and on, but I can't do this all day. Basically, I find Serious Sam to exceed in almost everything it does, and what it does, just never fails to amaze me in all the probable 1000+ hours I've probably played it in my lifetime. A closely followed community also backs up this game, giving you awesome access to mods, weapon models, gameplay tweaks, sound edits, and much more to make Serious Sam the game YOU choose it to be.It's absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing stunning. 10/10

												Man, do my wrists hurt!  And no, you clever so-and-so's, haha, very funny...no, it's NOT because that long-awaited nude footage of Scarlett Johansson in that weird alien movie recently plastered itself all over internet-land.  It's because I finally finished the last stage of Serious Sam: The First Encounter in a single sitting, and 4,467 enemies later I am♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥E-D, both mentally and physically.  Though the latter may, in all fairness, be mostly on account of the unfit, lazy turd which I admittedly am.  But I do have a strange, well-earned sense of "achievement" just the same, 'cause this game ain't no walk in the park, let me tell ya...   Recommending this game to the super-serious, look-at-me-I'm-such-a-badass-cos-I-play-VIDEO-GAMES-all-day-long league of uber-gamers is a bit of a no-brainer: It's long, it's hard, and it's positively RELENTLESS with the wave after wave after wave after wave (I'll stop there) of enemies which the game constantly throws at you.  Make no mistake, you'll kill a LOT of things in the course of this game.  With a wide array of weapons, of course: The ultimate being the "cannon ball", my personal fave, which is a bit like ten-pin bowling, with the nasty monsters filling in for the pins.  And there's a nice variety and eccentricity to said monsters, what's more: Headless kamikazes with bombs for hands, stampeding hordes of bull-like creatures which send you literally flying, wannabe Scorpion Kings with gattling guns...yup, it's a pretty crazy game.  Though perhaps not 100% original when you factor in the existence of, oh, I don't know, the DUKE NUKEM franchise perhaps?  But we know that Sam isn't actually Duke, because his t-shirt says so...so let's just put all the lawsuits down and play nice, whadya say, kids?   Yessir, this game is D-U-M-B, but undeniably fun.  And only occasionally so insanely hard that you feel like throwing it in altogether...but I guess it can't be THAT hard, if yours truly could finish the ♥♥♥♥er ('cause I am, in troll-speak, decidedly "♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; at these games, there's no denying).  Just don't expect the comparative intelligence of the Half Life games, for example, and you'll be fine.  Visit Ancient Egypt.  Kill stuff.  LOTS of stuff.  Now, isn't that the kind of moral message we want to be sending our kids?  Who said video games couldn't be edumacational?  They certainly show up the multitude of shortcomings in the formal education system...I can't recall ever being told about spaceships and laser guns and giant lava monsters in my Ancient History classes.  I've a good mind to sue the system for stunting my intellectual growth...Verdict: 8.5/10.

												I played Serious Sam : The First Encounter when it was released in 2001 and have always had fond memories of it since then . Tell you what , this game hasn't aged a single day . Most first person shooters do but not Serious Sam . Hear me out . Sure the visuals may feel somewhat repetative after a while but there is always a sense of grandness in the bright open outdoors with the sun shinning over the valley  . The indoors are often well desgined but still feel flat and clumsy sometimes . Their labyrinthian design can feel a bit dated and the gameplay gets very repetative , but its too much fun to be overlooked . Especially in short burts . The First Encounteris also a short game so it won't be a long tiresome journey either . The thing that works like a charm , personally is the gameplay . The shooting is a lot of fun . Espcially if you are into games like Killing Floor . You defend yourself while killing hordes of enemies that charge at you from all directions of the map or shoot at you from a high platform or tower . Once you clear an area a door opens and you move into the next area or map . Then rinse and repeat . Occasionally you have to collect a few items or hit a few switches to forward youself into the next map or level . Its solid fun if you ask me and well worth a try . It might be my nostalgia talking but I am frankly amazed at how good this game feels and runs on today's systems . Everything is butter smooth . No constant updates , no dlcs , no online crap . Just a great single player experience . Time I deal with The Second Enounter now ! Adios :)

What I liked about the game	Very impressive level design, the levels are huge, brilliant for fighting hundreds of enemies. The game has aged well the graphics still look good today. The skyboxes also look good and go well with the level. 	Good story, The PDA keeps you up-to-date on what's going on.  	Serious Sam is a brilliant protagonist who can be quite funny.   	Not a sad depressing game, it's very cheerful with its colourful levels, Sam's personality, and its comedy elements.	Hundreds of cool looking enemies to slaughter. You also have a great arsenal of weapons to slaughter your foes with. 	Many secrets to be found, plus there are secret levels. 	I like how serious Sam has his own PDA with A.I that talks to you through dialog. When you kill a new enemy or pick up a new weapon the PDA will provide information on that new weapon or enemy. 	I like the idea behind the map, telling you where you just been and where you are going to next. 	You can switch from first person to 3rd person. What I disliked or was disappointed with	Can be very challenging and frustrating, especially towards the end (I played on normal). Make sure you switch on auto save, because it was turned off when I first started playing game.   	The Egyptian setting got a bit boring towards the end.	The soundtrack isn't anything special.	The game does have a auto save system, but I would still recommend you save it manually frequently, because the auto save can save in the most inconvenient places. 	It's a shame Netricsa isn't voice acted.	The accuracy of some enemies can be a little too good.        ConclusionA very good game. You get a lot for your money. You get the original first encounter and the second encounter plus you get serious Sam revolution, which contains both the original games with some minor improvements, you also have survival mode and steam achievements, all for £7.99. I have also seen this game on sale at 90% off, regularly. If you like Painkiller or old school FPS games then I highly recommend you buy this.  82/100

Posted: July 7, 2014
												Serious Sam TFE displays what an arena shooter can pull off.The storyline? It sets the mood, that's about it, and that's all it really needs to do.You are sent into the past to kill off hundreds upon hundreds to even thousands of enemies from destroying the future. Simple enough?Serious Sam introduces literally the most memorable foes in any video game I've ever encountered. I remember each name, and all the stats because the game throws them in your face in a way that actually satisfies. Two shots per beheaded soldier, a quick shotgun blast to male Gnaars, double shotgun for those damn Kleers, loaded cannon to the major Biomechs! The best part is that these enemies rarely appear in troops, but in groups! You'll have a Biomech on one side, an Arachnoid on the other, an Aludran Reptilioid on the roof... how will you choose to approach this? It's all up to you and your powerful arsenal!Something also notable about Serious Sam is the stunning detail. Each enemy has a spot-on texture to make it feel like a true foe, and writings, paintings on the wall give for a total immersion into the mysterious landscape of Egypt. And how damn satisfying that is.Running through factual lands to kill fictional beasts has never, EVER been so pleasing. With a unique arsenal and engaging gameplay, Serious Sam gives you an un-parallelled journey to the beautiful land of Egypt with true to history level design.I could go on and on, but I can't do this all day. Basically, I find Serious Sam to exceed in almost everything it does, and what it does, just never fails to amaze me in all the probable 1000+ hours I've probably played it in my lifetime. A closely followed community also backs up this game, giving you awesome access to mods, weapon models, gameplay tweaks, sound edits, and much more to make Serious Sam the game YOU choose it to be.It's absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing stunning. 10/10

												One of the games that innovated FPS parody. Serious Sam: The First Encounter blends seamless FPS gameplay, with brilliant level design, and a goofy comedic sense of plotting. Sam Stone is the epitome of much of the late 90's FPS characters and it is with him that I get the most laughs. The enemies vary in some of the most ridiculous fashions. From headless infantry to undead bone predators; Serious Sam brings ridiculous to a whole new level. Nevertheless, it's sense of wit is much appreciated and fresh despite being such an old game. The biggest key here, however, is the design of Ancient Egypt. Breathtaking design and exquisite detail that bring Ancient Egypt to life like I have never seen before. Detailed messages detailing important aspects of Egyptian history, providing comedy and education. What a work of art Serious Sam is.
